profile.bio: Urbanist thinking about open places, open access, and open web/urbanism + https://zora.co/@miawintam
posts: Omg beautiful! I need to meet u in Denver
@tbsocialist is operating out of a cold plunge in Park Slope, nyc
Featured in artist Joshua Citarella's (love him) ongoing work 'e-deologies VI'
simple and like dark mode inverted, I like it
Pick an ok. Mines the blue 3D pill
Translucent creatures and the desire to be seen

No… I think on some apps, like whatsapp, I often get new contacts through group chats—but on signal or imessage, I usually add people directly, so maybe those chats feel more one-on-one and personal from the start
Definitely, numbers are more gated than usernames
I miss my 200 bots… they were my friends they gave me unconditional support

messaging people across different apps—imessage, signal, telegram, instagram dms, WhatsApp, feels different, even though, functionally, they're all instant messages that show up on my phone. certain platforms feel closer to me, like imessage, while others feel more distant? I'm not sure if this is an actual distinction or just a mental perception, but it's interesting how digital spaces create different psychological distances between people

My hot take is that sci-fi just doesn't hit like it used to. Because real life already feels like a never-ending dystopian saga. Like for example the new season of Black Mirror was kind of mid because it just felt…normal
